description: On May 4, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the framework under which schools, educational and childcare institutions are going to reopen from 11 May on. This encompasses age-appropriate hygiene measures and a combination of in-person and remote instructions for classes above class 5. In addition to this, classes are split into small groups.

description: On June 2, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the further relaxation of measures concerning schools and other educational institutions. However, some restrictions prevail. While in-person instructions are the standard, pupils at higher risk are allowed to use remote instructions. Mixtures of classes shall be avoided and school events and parent's evenings are prohibited. While sports classes are allowed, high-contact forms of sport shall be avoided and swim classes prohibited. Hygiene measurements are maintained.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On May 4, the gov of Liechtenstein announced the framework under which schools, educational and childcare institutions are going to reopen from 11 May on. This encompasses age-appropriate hygiene measures and a combination of in-person and remote instructions for classes above class 5. In addition to this, classes are split into small groups.
 UPDATE: On June 2, the gov of Liechtenstein announced that from June 8 on, in-person instructions are the new normal for all grades. In addition to this, classes aren't split up in groups anymore but taught together.

description: The Government of Liechtenstein has announced that they will start vaccinating people from January 18. Nursing homes and the most vulnerable people in it will be the first ones to receive their vaccination. Next the nursing staff (of nursing homes, curative education, family assistance and hospitals) will get their chance to get vaccinated. Next in line are the vulnerable staff of the primary health care and the residents of nursing homes in descending order (age).
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On March 16th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council votes to extend border checks from Italy to France, Austria and Germany. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
On March 13th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council re-opens federal border checks including Schengen checks, designed to limit incoming and outgoing traffic to Italy. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
 UPDATE: On March 16th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council votes to extend border checks from Italy to France, Austria and Germany. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: The Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states except for the principality of Lichtenstein on March 25th 2020. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein. The previous policy only applied to entrants from Italy, France, Germany and Austria.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description:
On March 16th 2020, the Swiss Federal Council votes to extend border checks from Italy to France, Austria and Germany. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein to Austria. Only Swiss and Liechtenstein citizens, people with a residence permit in Switzerland or Liechtenstein and people who have to travel to Switzerland or Liechtenstein for professional reasons are allowed to enter. Transit and goods traffic are also allowed. Finally, people in a situation of absolute necessity may also enter from.
On March 25th, this was extended to entry restrictions concerning all Schengen states and non-Schengen states.
 UPDATE: Initially, border restrictions only applied on Italy, France, Germany and Austria. On March 25th, the Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
The Swiss Federal Council extends entry restrictions/border checks to include all Schengen states and non-Schengen states except for the principality of Lichtenstein on March 25th 2020. As Switzerland is in charge for border control of the Liechtenstein border, this applies also for the border of Liechtenstein. The previous policy only applied to entrants from Italy, France, Germany and Austria.

 UPDATE: On May 15th, the government of Liechtenstein announced that from June 15th on, the border to Austria will be open again as usual.
type_sub_cat: Visa restrictions (e.g. suspend issuance of visa)
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: The government of Liechtenstein announced that from February 10 2021 people who want to travel to Austria are required to fill out a questionnaire online and provide a negative COVID test (not older than 7 days). If they are not able to provide a test they are required to provide one 24h after entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The government of Liechtenstein announced that from February 10 2021 people who want to travel to Austria are required to fill out a questionnaire online and provide a negative COVID test (not older than 7 days). If they are not able to provide a test they are required to provide one 24h after entry.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 14, Liechtenstein ordered skiers coming home from abroad to observe their health carefully.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of April 15, 2020, Liechtenstein announced new research and measures into better surveillance and monitoring of the spread of the coronavirus. This includes a pilot research project using elderly wrist bands for early covid-19 detection as well as monitoring waste water.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 29 the gov of Liechtenstein publicly recommended to use the SwissCovidApp - programmed and used in Switzerland - for the improvement of contact tracing. The installation of the app is voluntarily.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 23, 2020, Liechtenstein announces to increase hospital capacities by postponing non-essential surgeries and adding capacities at hospitals and implements drive-through testing.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

 UPDATE: From April 27 all surgeries can be performed again.

description: On June 24, the government of Liechtenstein recommended to store up to 50 face masks per individual for a potential second wave.

description: From August 31 until October 2, students in all schools in Liechtenstein will be tested weekly.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 11, Liechtenstein banned visits to elderly homes to at least March 25, 2020.
The Government of Liechtenstein advises citizens over 65 years old and citizens with pre existing conditions on March 16, 2020 to stay at home and avoid social interactions if possible.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 11, 2020, Liechtenstein "set up a "new coronavirus 2019-nCoV" staff, which, under the chairmanship of the government councilor Mauro Pedrazzini, will monitor developments related to the new coronavirus and coordinate necessary measures for Liechtenstein."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From March 26, 2020, Liechtenstein partly lifts a Sunday- and nigh-ban on trucks to ensure smooth supply lines.
type_text: Liechtenstein partly lifts a ban on trucks to ensure smooth supply lines
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 26, it was announced that Liechtenstein is prepared for the coronavirus and methods of disease prevention were made public.
On March 18, 2020, Liechtenstein implemented an information hotline.
The police has started the campaign #stayathome on 03-21-2020 targeted at youths and young adults to remind them of the rules and deter them from gathering in large numbers.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 5, 2020, Liechtenstein announced a public awareness campaign targeting schools. The campaign will be called #HebenSorg. Posters and flyers explaining the most important hygiene measures to students. The campaign also extends to social media and the government websites as well as to question panel with the education minister allowing students to ask questions.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19

description: On July 3 the gov of Liechtenstein announced that a 10-day quarantine will be imposed on all travelers who has been in a country of risk in the preceding 14 days, starting on July 6. The list is initiated and updated by the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health (FOPH) and currently encompasses Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bolivia, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Dominican Republic, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Qatar, Columbia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Republic of Moldova, Republic of North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi-Arabia, Sweden, Serbia, South Africa, Turks and Caicos Islands as well as the USA.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On July 23, the Federal Office of Public Health of Switzerland updated the list of high risks countries which the government of Liechtenstein adopts. People having been in the countries in the preceding 14 days have to go into 10-day quarantine. The initial policy started on July 6. The list currently encompasses Argentina, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnien und Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini/Swasiland, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Israel, Qatar, Columbia, Kazakhstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Kyrgyzstan, Luxembourg, Maldives, Mexico, Republic of Moldova, Montenegro, Palestine, Republic of North Macedonia, Oman, Panama, Peru, Russia, Saudi-Arabia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turks and Caicos Islands, UAE as well as the USA.

description:
From December 19 all travellers from a country or area with increased risk of infection are required to quarantine for 10 days following their entry.
For a definition of 'increased risk' as well as exceptions to the rule see the COVID-19 Ordinance on International Passenger Transport Measures (Switzerland status 12-19-2020).

Countries/ areas with increased risk of infection:
Andorra
Croatia
Georgia
Lithuania
Luxembourg
Montenegro
San Marino
Serbia
Slovenia
United States of America

Various areas in Italy
target_geog_level: One or more other geographical or administrative units within one or more countries (e.g. county)

description:
From December 21 all travellers from a country or area with increased risk of infection are required to quarantine for 10 days following their entry.
For a definition of 'increased risk' as well as exceptions to the rule see the COVID-19 Ordinance on International Passenger Transport Measures (Switzerland status 12-21-2020).
Persons who entered Switzerland from the United Kingdom or South Africa on or after 14 December 2020 must go into quarantine by midnight on 21 December 2020 at the latest.

Countries/ areas with increased risk of infection:
Andorra
Croatia
Georgia
Lithuania
Luxembourg

description:
From December 19 all travellers from a country or area with increased risk of infection are required to quarantine for 10 days following their entry.
For a definition of 'increased risk' as well as exceptions to the rule see the COVID-19 Ordinance on International Passenger Transport Measures (Switzerland status 12-19-2020).

Countries/ areas with increased risk of infection:
Andorra
Croatia
Georgia
Lithuania
Luxembourg
Montenegro
San Marino
Serbia
Slovenia
United States of America

Various areas in Italy
 UPDATE: On December 21, 2020 United Kingdom or South Africa were added to the list of high risk countries.
target_geog_level: One or more other geographical or administrative units within one or more countries (e.g. county)

description:
From December 28 all travellers from a country or area with increased risk of infection are required to quarantine for 10 days following their entry.
1 There is an increased risk of infection with the Sars-Cov-2 coronavirus if at least one of the following requirements is satisfied:
a.3 In the past 14 days the number of new infections per 100 000 persons in the country or area concerned is more than 60 higher than in Switzerland, and this number is not due to specific incidents or cases occurring in a narrowly defined geographical area.
b. The available information from the country or area concerned does not allow a reliable assessment to be made of the risk situation, and there are indica-tions that there is an increased risk of transmission in the country or area concerned.
c. In the past four weeks, there have been repeated instances of infected per-sons who have stayed in the country or area concerned entering Switzerland.
d.4 In the country or area concerned, a mutation of the coronavirus Sars-CoV-2 is spreading that carries a higher risk of infection than the form of the virus that is prevalent in Switzerland.

For a detailed list of the exceptions to the quarantine requirement please see the linked source.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
From December 21 all travellers from a country or area with increased risk of infection are required to quarantine for 10 days following their entry.
For a definition of 'increased risk' as well as exceptions to the rule see the COVID-19 Ordinance on International Passenger Transport Measures (Switzerland status 12-21-2020).
Persons who entered Switzerland from the United Kingdom or South Africa on or after 14 December 2020 must go into quarantine by midnight on 21 December 2020 at the latest.

Countries/ areas with increased risk of infection:
Andorra
Croatia
Georgia
Lithuania
Luxembourg
Montenegro
San Marino
Serbia
Slovenia
United States of America

Various areas in Italy UPDATE: On December 28 the list of countries with increased risk of infection was updated.
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events and gathers to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March.

On March 13, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events and gathering to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020 UPDATE: The restriction is extended to the April 30, 2020, and increased to only allow events of a maximum of 100 people, instead of the prior 1000.
On March 16, 2020, Liechtenstein further prohibits private and public events and gatherings of more than 5 people.

On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March. 
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
 UPDATE: Originally, the restriction of events to a maximum of 100 people was set to at least end of April, as of March 16 the limit was set to 5 people max indefinitely

On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March. 
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
On March 16, the level was set to a maximum of 5 people indefinitely.
 UPDATE: From March 19, all events are banned.

On March 16, 2020, Liechtenstein further prohibits private and public events and gatherings of more than 5 people.
 UPDATE: On May 20, the government of Liechtenstein announced to replace the previous ban of gatherings of more than 5 people in public by an obligatory distance of 2m between people of different households. However, private and public events remain prohibited.

On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March. 
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
On March 16, the level was set to a maximum of 5 people indefinitely.
From March 19, all events were banned.
 UPDATE: From June 6 public and private events with up to 300 people are allowed again, as long as they have a valid hygiene concept (not necessary for e.g. family gatherings where the organizer knows all the guests).

On February 28, 2020, Liechtenstein restricted events to a maximum of 1,000 people until at least the 15th of March. 
On March 13, 2020, the level was set to a maximum of 100 people until at least the April 30, 2020.
On March 16, the level was set to a maximum of 5 people indefinitely.
On March 19, all events were banned.
From June 6 public and private events were allowed again with up to 300 people. UPDATE: From July 3 events with up to 1000 people are allowed again (with valid hygiene concepts).
The gov of Liechtenstein decided to cancel the traditional festivities of the national holiday and opt for an alternative way to celebrate in compliance with the Covid rules .
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From October 15 the Government of Liechtenstein is restricting the the group size in restaurants to max. 6 people per table. Drinking and eating while standing is no longer allowed (like in bars/ clubs). The general hygiene rules (like min. distance between people) have to be followed as well.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 15 2021 the government of Liechtenstein announced that, in order to protect employees even better, wearing a mask when indoors and more than 1 person is present in the room is mandatory. This policy is also applicable when the person is in a vehicle. The policy is set to last until further notice.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 15 2021 the government of Liechtenstein announced that wearing a mask in schools will be mandatory going forward. This mandate is applicable to students older than 12 years and the school staff. PE lessons, as well as music lessons and speech-language lessons (lessons/ therapy sessions which would be severely hindered by a mask) are exempt from the policy. The policy is set to last until further notice.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
